Consistent, clear guidance overall: get vaccinated when you are eligible, wear a mask, avoid crowds, socially distance, dont travel unless its essential. Need to keep up the collective work to bring this pandemic under control. 7/end
New data also shows how vaccination protects against wild type and variants. People should get vaccinated to protect themselves and their families and communities. 6/

New data shows that COVID was the cause of 11% of all US deaths in 2020, quite disproportionately affecting people of color. Focus on reaching vulnerable populations with vaccine, testing, interventions more important than ever 5/

COVID cases increased by 12% in last week, hospitalizations increasing, with number of people dying continuing to be about 900 people, every day. Need to strengthen our response and slow the spread. 4/
12 more federally run mass vax sites coming, which each will be able to vaccinate 3000 people a day. Comes on top of 25 fed mass vax sites that together vaccinate 95,000 people a day. 3/
There are more than 50,000 vaccine sites now across the country. Within 3 weeks, there will be ~70,000 locations, as the number of pharmacies that are vaccinating doubles. 2/

Many in @CDCgov, US pharmacies, health depts and public health community have long seen the promise of utilizing pharmacies as part of a national mass vaccination program. It's terrific important that the program is getting started. 8/end

... stores around country, a sizable portion of which are in underrepresented zip codes; ability to manage the cold chain required; ability to move vaccine around w/ their distribution systems to try to match demand with supply. 7/x

The fed pharm program takes advantage of capabilities pharmacies already have in place: administrative, logistical and vaccination workforce house; IT systems that can schedule 1st and 2nd appts; tech to communicate by text w/ pts; ability to give epi for allergies, ... 6/x

Quite distinct from long term care pharmacy COVID program. In that program, pharmacies had to schedule visits to facilities, and were challenged by that, by holidays, by low sign-up in many places. The new program will happen in stores, less barriers to success and speed. 5/x

Overall it has 21 chain + independent pharmacies representing > 40K locations with more getting vaccine as supply and success allow. A key factor considered in selection of the pharmacies in each state is their ability to reach populations most at risk for severe illness. 4/x

These pharmacies are the same that people use daily for the country, where many people already get their flu shots. The number of stores having COVID vaccine will be limited to start, but with time and as they show success, the number will grow. 3/x

Will create additional new path for people to get vaccinated around country. Direct pharmacy allocation will be in addition to the 10.5M doses being delivered weekly that states will administer (this is a dose number which has increased some since end of last week.) 2/x

Big announcement about the vaccine roll out today is the start of the Fed retail pharmacy partnership for COVID vaccination. Excited to see this program get started Feb 11 and think it has high potential. 1/x https://t.co/gglFmzNaro

Admin encouraging physicians and states to not hold back vaccine at this point because vaccine delivery now more consistent and holding back not necessary. If this happens, then daily vax rate will go up. 6/end
As of a couple weeks ago, less than 50% of vaccine delivered to states had been administered, now it is up to 62% and Admin will continue to monitor this number daily; 5/x
1.3M vaccinations being administered a day; 25M have gotten a first dose, 31M doses delivered all together; Means 1/10 US adults have gotten at least first dose 4/x

Congress should pass the American Rescue Plan to provide funding to accelerate and strengthen the vaccination program (community vax clinics, mobile clinics, free vaccine etc) and expand genomic surveillance for variants, and accelerate other COVID relief efforts. 13/end
As long as the virus thrives, evolves, mutates anywhere in the world, it will be a threat to everywhere in the world. 12/x

Very important to vaccinate the US population given the terrible illness and mortality from this disease in our country. But we have to be big donor and part of the global vaccination effort too. 11/x

Discovery of variants and clear evolution of this virus around the world means that there will continue to be major threat posed by this virus until there is successful global vaccination effort everywhere. 10/x
JJ promises 100M doses to US by June (which could hugely accelerate US vaccination effort) as well as 1B doses for world in 2021 (which will hugely accelerate global vaccination effort). 9/x

Terrific press release on JJ vax 85% efficacy in protecting against severe COVID at 28 days in wildtype, UK and S. African strains, and no deaths after 49 days. One dose will make administration faster + easier. Need to see data, and FDA to review, but great news so far. 8/x
Important to see all of Pfizer shipments now coming with syringe that allows use of that 6th dose thats one more dose with every single vial (of previously 5 doses.) 7/x

Great development that US Public Health Service Commissioned Corps officers being activated to assist on the ground vaccination efforts. And that FEMA giving out $1B in assistance to states and to have 200 FEMA officials on the ground now helping with state vax efforts. 6/x
Very good to see that HHS revised the Prep Act to increase the number of vaccinators around the country by allowing retired nurses and doctors to do COVID vaccination. 5/x

Still wide range of coverage across US. Some states have given 6 doses per 100 people, others 13. Overall nearly 50M doses have been delivered to states, and about 31M have been administered. Hopefully states will be able to continue to close the gap. 4/x https://t.co/wXcqSHvS60

There are now stable dose projections for next 3 weeks 10M doses to be distributed nationally per week -a 16% increase. States have been asking for this stability, and it should help them in their planning efforts. 3/x

We will need to accelerate vaccination numbers further as soon as vaccine production allows, but the numbers of daily vaccinations moving in right direction. Now is the time to be rapidly scaling up capacity to administer in all states. 2/x

Very encouraged by the moves forward this week in the US vaccination effort. An average of 1.2-1.3M doses a day being administered across the country now (up from 700k-800K 2 wks ago). 1/x https://t.co/GYhUH4abqK

Finally - Congress should pass the American Rescue Plan to fund these programs to slow this pandemic down, increase funding to make schools a lot safer, expand testing + PPE and other important COVID efforts. 14/end
And of course its critical for people to get vaccinated when they get the opportunity. 13/x

If you work or go to a school in an indoor place outside the home, then do what you can to improve ventilation and air filtration. We also should have paid leave in place to make sure people who are sick or exposed can stay home without losing their paychecks. 12/x

Dangers posed by the ongoing pandemic in the US and the spread of variants here also mean we should physically distance, avoid large gatherings, stay home when sick and get tested, remain isolated after exposure. And it means 11/x

Masks should be 2 or 3 ply woven fabric, as per CDC, should fit snugly over nose/on cheeks and under chin so that air goes through the mask, not around the edges. Hold your mask up to the light and it should block the light out (or its too thin). 10/x https://t.co/EeqvjXUnxD

University of Washington study this week concluded that we would save more than 30,000 lives in next 3 months if 95% of us wore masks consistently. (That would mean hundreds of thousands of hospitalizations and millions of infections avoided too) 9/x
To start, this means we should all be wearing masks when out of our houses and near any other people. Even now just 75% of country wears masks consistently, and some states it's as low as 50% 8/x
Its also very clear the virus is evolving and may continue to do so in dangerous ways, and the best way to stop new mutations from appearing is to diminish the number of people who get infected. 7/x

While tests done show far show vaccines seem to continue to provide strong protection against variants, the variants accelerate transmissibility (which will lead to more people dying), and the UK strain may also directly increase mortality risk in an individual who gets it 6/x
Given the minimal surveillance in US, we need to presume that our number are much higher for all the variants of concern, and act accordingly. 5/x
Very low level of genomic surveillance in US up until now (though that is starting to change) compared to the UK which does genomic surveillance on 5-10% of every COVID case. 4/x
